This study utilized census data from Henan Province for the years 2000, 2010, and 2020 to investigate the spa- tiotemporal evolution of population aging, deﬁned by the proportion of the population aged 65 and above. Employing spatial analysis techniques such as spatial autocorrelation and the standard deviation ellipse, the research mapped out the progression and distribution of aging demographics. Furthermore, the study delved into the inﬂuencing factors of aging using an optimal parameters-based geographical detector. Results indicate a deepening degree of population aging in Henan Province, transitioning from an adult type to an old type structure. There is a marked positive spatial correlation among counties, with high-value aging areas initially decreasing, then increasing, and notably spreading from the central to the central and southern regions of the province. The center of gravity for population aging, speciﬁcally around Changge City and Xuchang City, exhibits a trajectory moving southeast before shifting northwest. Addressing the aforementioned challenges, this study adheres to established standards and com- bines insights from prior research to categorize the types of population age structures. Utilizing ag- ing data from three temporal benchmarks—2000, 2010, and 2020—across various districts and coun- ties of Henan Province, this study examines the spatiotemporal distribution and evolutionary pat- terns of population aging. Furthermore, it employs an optimal parameters-based geographical detector model to quantitatively assess the drivers behind the spatial differentiation of aging across the region. The findings aim to furnish precise recommenda- tions to mitigate the impacts of population aging and promote the development of aging policies.

In light of an aging population, researchers pre- dominantly investigate the spatial distribution, in- fluencing mechanisms, and evolutionary trends of the aging population. Utilizing diverse analytical methods like cloud models, population centers of gravity, and exploratory spatial data analysis, re- searchers have clarified the spatiotemporal char- acteristics of population aging across provincial, urban, and county levels[4-6]. To further explore the spatial patterns of aging, various mathemati- cal methods including spatial econometric models, classical regression, geographically weighted regres- sion, and ordinary least squares have been employed to analyze the causes behind regional aging dispari- ties, focusing on demographic, economic, social, and environmental dimensions[7-9]. Additionally, stud- ies integrating population forecasting, grey mod- els, econometric approaches, and the Wolfson index model have shed light on regional aging variations and trends[10-12]. Moreover, researchers in gerontol- ogy and related fields provide strategic recommen- dations for managing aging populations and allocat- ing pension resources by exploring pension security issues, including pension modes and services[13-15]. Population aging, a social phenomenon driven by changes in demographic structures, is influenced by various factors including demographic, economic, social, and environmental elements. To determine its impact on the age structure, this study reviews the literatures to identify factors previously used and assesses their data availability and relevance. Consequently, the factors influencing aging in each district and county of Henan Province are catego- rized into two main groups[20-23]: direct and indi- rect factors. Demographic factors comprise birth rate, death rate, migration rate, and the percent- age of the population aged 55∼64 in the previous census. Economic factors include Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and general public budget expen- diture. Social factors encompass the percentage of women of childbearing age (15∼49), number of beds in health institutions, aged-child ratio, and elderly dependency ratio. In total, 10 influencing factors are analyzed (see Tab. 2). Economic factors. The regional GDP serves as an indicator of both the overall economic strength and the development speed of a region. General pub- lic budget expenditure, on the other hand, reflects the government’s financial commitment to public services. Higher levels of regional GDP and public budget expenditure enable local governments to en- hance social security systems more effectively. This, in turn, allows the elderly population to access im- Demographic factors. The relative changes in birth and mortality rates directly influence the de- gree of population aging within a region. An in- creased birth rate results in a higher proportion of the younger population, which consequently re- duces the aging rate. Conversely, a decrease in proved life and medical care services, pensions, and other support systems, which may indirectly reduce mortality rates, boost birth rates, and attract mi- grants. Consequently, there may be a correlation between regional GDP and public budget expen- diture and the spatial differentiation observed in population aging. Social factors. The aged-child ratio, which com- pares the number of elderly individuals aged 65 and above to the number of young individuals aged 0∼14, provides insights into the age structure of the regional population. A higher aged-child ratio sug- gests a smaller incoming population and potentially deeper aging. The elderly dependency ratio, which is the proportion of the elderly population aged 65 and above relative to the working-age population aged 15∼64, indicates the level of support available for the elderly in the region. Regions with a lower old-age dependency ratio may offer better care for the elderly, possibly leading to increased life ex- pectancy and impacting the region’s aging dynam- ics. Additionally, the proportion of women of child- bearing age (15∼49) can influence regional birth rates, thus affecting aging trends; while the number of beds in health institutions reflects the availability of medical resources. In regions with adequate med- ical resources, the elderly are more likely to have access to suﬀicient medical care, potentially extend- ing life expectancy. Therefore, factors such as the aged-child ratio, elderly dependency ratio, the pro- portion of women of childbearing age (15∼49), and the number of beds in health institutions are likely to exhibit spatial correlations with population ag- ing patterns. Geodetector[29-31] is a spatial analysis tool used to detect spatial heterogeneity and identify the un- derlying driving forces. Traditional applications of Geodetector often rely on the manual selection or comparison of multiple classification methods to discretize continuous variables, a process that can be highly subjective and potentially yield subopti- mal discretization results, thus affecting the relia- bility of the detection results. To address these lim- itations, this study employs an optimal parameters- based geographical detector[32-34]. Utilizing the GD package in R, this approach incorporates five clas- sification methods—equal interval, natural break- point, quantile, geometric interval, and standard deviation—to discretize spatial data. The config- uration yielding the highest q value is selected to ensure the most effective spatial discretization. Additionally, interaction detection was employed to assess the combined influence of two indepen- dent variables on population aging. By comparing the q values from the interaction of different in- fluencing factors with the results from single-factor detections, it is possible to determine the presence and extent of interaction between the two factors. This includes identifying five types of interactions: nonlinear weakening, single-factor nonlinear weak- ening, bivariate enhancement, independence, and nonlinear enhancement. To explore the driving forces behind the spatial distribution of population aging in Henan Province from 2000 to 2020, data from ten influencing fac- tors across demographic, economic, and social di- mensions for 2010 and 2020 were analyzed. These factors were treated as independent variables, with the aging status of each district and county serv- ing as the dependent variable. However, due to the absence of previous census data on the proportion of the population aged 55∼64 in 2000, only nine influencing factors were utilized for this period. Us- ing an optimal parameters-based geographical de- tector, each continuous variable was classified us- ing five methods: equal interval, natural breakpoint, quantile, geometric, and standard deviation classi- fication. The number of categories was set between four and nine to identify the parameter combina- tion yielding the highest q value, as detailed in Tab. 6. Furthermore, the oblateness of the ellipse in- creased, with the most significant change occur- ring between 2000 and 2010. This adjustment is attributed to an accelerated aging process in south- eastern Henan, which influenced the directional shift of the ellipse. Between 2010 and 2020, the change in ellipse oblateness markedly decreased, in- dicating a stabilization in the rate of aging across the various regions during this decade.
